Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Nab \Nab\ (n[a^]b), n. [Cf. {Knap}, {Knop}, {Knob}.] 1. The summit of an eminence. [Prov. Eng.] --Halliwell. [1913 Webster]
2. (Firearms) The cock of a gunlock. --Knight. [1913 Webster]
3. (Locksmithing) The keeper, or box into which the lock is shot. --Knight. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Nab \Nab\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Nabbed} (n[a^]bd); p. pr. & vb. n. {Nabbing}.] [Dan nappe, or Sw. nappa.] 1. To catch or seize suddenly or unexpectedly. [Colloq.] --Smollett. [1913 Webster]
2. To capture; to arrest; as, the police nabbed the culprit wtrying to hide in the basement. [PJC]

Dictionary.Name: Virtual Entity of Relevant Acronyms (Version 1.9, June 2002)

Definition.WordDefinition: NAB National Association of Broadcasters (org., USA)

Dictionary.Name: Virtual Entity of Relevant Acronyms (Version 1.9, June 2002)

Definition.WordDefinition: nab v 1: tag the base runner to get him out 2: take into custody; "the police nabbed the suspected criminals" [syn: {collar}, {nail}, {apprehend}, {arrest}, {pick up}, {cop}] 3: seize suddenly [also: {nabbing}, {nabbed}]
